title: What are the sensations and experiences of being hypnotized, as described by Auguste Queff?
first_phrase: In the previous paragraphs, the author expressed his skepticism towards anything that goes beyond the natural and ordinary, suggesting their association with deception and charlatanism. However, to judge fairly, he decided to experience it himself. In the last 200 tokens, he elaborates on his experience of being hypnotized by a skilled mesmerist named Donato, and how it added a new mystery to his understanding of scientific phenomena. He was unable to perceive any external sensation during the cataleptic state induced by the mesmerist, and he obeyed Donato's commands without any recollection of doing so. This led him to conclude that there were two distinct sensations that a "subject" experiences, one being mere fascination and the other complete detachment.
content: Le magnétiseur me parle-t-il?je l’entends plutôt, si je puis ainsi m'exprimer, comme une voix intérieure, pour obéir aux commandements de laquelle il m’est d’ailleurs complètement impossible de tenter aucun mouvement. « En effet, quand M. Donato me réveille (le terme est propre ici) je ne puis me souvenir d’aucune des choses que j’ai faites ou plutôt que m’a fait faire l’habile magnétiseur entre les mains duquel j’ai, à mon insu, abdiqué ma volonté personnelle, immédiatement et exclusivement remplacée par la sienne propre. « Je conclus qu'il est éprouvé par le « sujet » deux sensations d'un ordre tout à fait différent. Dans la première, il n’est que fasciné et peut se rappeler ce que le magnétiseur lui a dit ou fait faire ; dans la seconde, il est plongé dans une torpeur magnétique qui lui enlève toute notion et jusqu’au moindre souvenir do ce qu’il a fait.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the experience of Auguste Queff with Mr. Donato as a magnetizer showed two distinct sensations- one where he was only fascinated and could remember what was said or done, and another where he was plunged into a magnetic stupor and had no recollection of any actions. While some may question the use of an external agent like electricity, Queff denies feeling any such commotion. Ultimately, as Queff admits his ignorance of the causes behind his experience, he invites others to do the same.
